name: Mercury
summary: Mercury is the closest planet to the Sun and the smallest of the eight planets.
facts: A Mercury day is very long: one sunrise to the next lasts about 176 Earth days.
It has almost no atmosphere, so temperatures swing from extremely hot to extremely cold.
Its surface is covered with craters, similar to the Moon.
howToSpot: Look very low near the horizon shortly after sunset or before sunrise. It is never far from the Sun in the sky.
funFact: Because it stays close to the Sun, Mercury is often hard to observe for long.

name: Venus
summary: Venus is a bright planet often called the Morning Star or Evening Star.
facts: Venus has thick clouds and a very strong greenhouse effect, making it the hottest planet.
Its rotation is very slow and opposite the direction of most planets (retrograde).
It is similar in size to Earth, but its surface conditions are extreme.
howToSpot: Find the brightest 'star' near the Sun after sunset or before sunrise. Venus is usually the brightest object in the sky after the Moon.
funFact: On Venus, a day is longer than a year.

name: Earth
summary: Earth is our home planet and the only one known to have liquid water on the surface and life.
facts: About 71% of Earth's surface is covered by oceans.
Earth's atmosphere protects life and helps keep temperatures stable.
Earth has one natural satellite: the Moon.
howToSpot: In a sky app, Earth is usually not shown in the sky view because you are standing on it.
funFact: Earth's magnetic field helps shield us from charged particles from the Sun.

name: Mars
summary: Mars is often called the Red Planet because of iron rich dust on its surface.
facts: Mars has two small moons: Phobos and Deimos.
A day on Mars is close to an Earth day: about 24.6 hours.
Mars has the largest volcano in the solar system: Olympus Mons.
howToSpot: Mars often looks like a bright reddish 'star'. It can be very bright during good oppositions.
funFact: Mars is a key target for robotic exploration and future human missions.

name: Jupiter
summary: Jupiter is the largest planet and a gas giant with many moons.
facts: Jupiter has a famous storm called the Great Red Spot.
It rotates very fast, taking about 10 hours to spin once.
You can often see its four largest moons (Galilean moons) with binoculars.
howToSpot: Jupiter looks like a very bright, steady light. If you zoom in, you may notice small points (moons) lined up beside it.
funFact: Jupiter's strong gravity helps shape the paths of many objects in the solar system.

name: Saturn
summary: Saturn is a gas giant famous for its bright ring system.
facts: Saturn's rings are made of countless pieces of ice and rock.
It is less dense than water, meaning it would float in a giant ocean (as a thought experiment).
Saturn has many moons; Titan is the largest and has a thick atmosphere.
howToSpot: Saturn looks like a bright, steady star. Through a small telescope, its rings are usually visible.
funFact: Saturn's rings are very wide but extremely thin compared to their width.

name: Uranus
summary: Uranus is an ice giant and appears as a small blue green disk through larger telescopes.
facts: Uranus rotates on its side, with an extreme tilt of about 98 degrees.
It has faint rings and many moons.
Its blue green color comes from methane in the atmosphere.
howToSpot: Hard to see with the naked eye. Best found by searching in the app and then using binoculars or a telescope at a dark site.
funFact: Because it is tilted, Uranus has very unusual seasons.

name: Neptune
summary: Neptune is the farthest major planet from the Sun and is an ice giant with strong winds.
facts: Neptune has some of the fastest winds in the solar system.
It appears deep blue due to methane and atmospheric effects.
It has a large moon named Triton.
howToSpot: Not visible to most people without a telescope. Use the app search and a telescope to locate it.
funFact: Neptune was the first planet found using math predictions before it was widely observed.

name: Sun
summary: The Sun is a star at the center of our solar system and provides the light and heat that support life on Earth.
facts: The Sun is a ball of hot plasma where nuclear fusion turns hydrogen into helium.
It contains most of the solar system's mass.
Sunlight takes about 8 minutes to reach Earth.
howToSpot: Never look directly at the Sun without proper eye protection. Use safe solar filters for observation.
funFact: The Sun's magnetic activity can create sunspots and solar flares.

name: Moon
summary: The Moon is Earth's natural satellite and changes appearance through phases as it orbits Earth.
facts: The Moon's phases are caused by how much of its sunlit side we can see from Earth.
The same side of the Moon generally faces Earth (tidal locking).
The Moon's gravity causes most ocean tides on Earth.
howToSpot: The Moon is easy to see and is a great object for binoculars or a small telescope, especially near first quarter when shadows show craters clearly.
funFact: The Moon is moving away from Earth by a few centimeters each year.
